title: suggestions for large font families
content:
hi all,

I am starting a typographically based art project. I would like to use one large font family - i.e., several weights, italics, ligatures (standard and discretionary, if possible), etc. Less commonly used glyphs like fractions and so forth are not as important. Also, it should simply be beautiful. (Open to interpretation, of course.)

I’m leaning toward serif faces but both sans and serif are welcome. Feel free to throw out the usual suspects, but I’m also interested in more, let’s say, obscure possibilities.

Of course, it has to be purchasable (not proprietary).

thanks much!  
jarrod
author: begsini

comments.content:
Paul,

Are you asking out of curiosity, are because you think you need to know more before you make a suggestion? I’m not ready to reveal the underlying concept yet, but if you have a specific question you think is relevant, I will try to answer it.

jarrod

The Leitura type system from Dino dos Santos is large, with two different serifs, a sans and a headline font variations.

And it’s 50% off for February at [Myfonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20090531082729/http:/www.myfonts.com/browse/foundry/dstype/).

hey everyone,

thanks for your suggestions so far - i am enjoying looking through them and some are definitely in the running.

one thing i had not considered was that some “families” contain both sans and serifs. for example, FF Quadraat as Jelmar suggested or Scala + Scala Sans.

it may be a matter of semantics, but would you all consider serif versions and sans versions to be in the same family? or each their own family?

to explain a bit further what i want to do: i will be making a large scale visual tapestry of many distinct pieces of text, ranging from two word phrases to a few sentences. so on one level, the viewer will be able to experience the piece as a purely visual thing, like a painting. on another level, as viewers moves closer to the piece, they will be able to read each individual statement, which - i hope - will provide a whole other level of dialogue with the piece.

what do you all think about a sans and serif together in this context?

thanks!  
jarrod

Usually the sans and serif faces that are in one family, are designed to work well together. The one may be derived from the other. Or designed individually, but staying close to each other. Usually there is something like a ’skeleton’, so to speak, to be seen, on which both faces are based.

But I’m not sure if I would call it ’one’ family. Most of them are sold seprately, so based on that I would say they are not.

_it may be a matter of semantics, but would you all consider serif versions and sans versions to be in the same family? or each their own family?_

See [super family](http://web.archive.org/web/20090531082729/http:/typophile.com/wiki/super%252Bfamily).

I think you should consider [Beorcana](http://web.archive.org/web/20090531082729/http:/beorcana.com/). It’s got a bit of that pen-formed/blackletter feel to it, linking it to [textura](http://web.archive.org/web/20090531082729/http:/typophile.com/wiki/textura), which was thus named because of its appearance of lines being woven together... hopefully that make some sense to someone besides me. ;^p

A super family for me contains more “styles” than serif/sans-serif, or slab/sans. Thesis for example.  
Hmm but then, how would i call a extremely large\* Serif/Sans family? Mini-super family :)
